channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: World Leaders Mull a Potential Second Term for Trump
item.description: Some governments are taking concrete steps to prepare for the possible return of the former U.S. president.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne
item.media:credit: Jon Cherry for The New York Times
item.media:description: With Donald J. Trump consistently polling ahead of President Biden, some governments around the world are taking concrete steps to prepare for the possibility of a second Trump administration.

item.title: As Many South Koreans Shun Marriage, Two Women Try to Redefine Family
item.description: Hwang Sunwoo and Kim Hana, who are single and live together, say South Korea’s laws should reflect the alternative unions that many of its people have chosen.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:credit: Woohae Cho for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hwang Sunwoo, left, and Kim Hana in Seoul. The two women, who have a best-selling book and a podcast, call themselves “a DIY family.”

item.title: France Parliament Re-elects Yaël Braun-Pivet for National Assembly President
item.description: A left-wing bloc that won the most seats in legislative elections this month called the re-election of Yaël Braun-Pivet, an ally of President Emmanuel Macron, a denial of democracy.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen and Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Yaël Braun-Pivet, a centrist ally of President Emmanuel Macron, ascends the podium after winning re-election as president of France’s National Assembly on Thursday in Paris.

item.title: Evan Gershkovich, Wall Street Journal Reporter, Returns to Court in Russia
item.description: Mr. Gershkovich, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal, appeared at a hearing in his espionage trial. The United States and The Journal have strongly rejected the charge against him.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Evan Gershkovich, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal, during a hearing in Russia last month.

item.title: In Argentina, Milei’s Devotion to Judaism Influences His Politics
item.description: Javier Milei has developed a public devotion to Judaism unusual for a leader of a predominantly Roman Catholic country.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Daniel Politi
item.media:description: President Javier Milei of Argentina, right, during an emotional visit to the Western Wall in Jerusalem in February with his rabbi, Shimon Axel Wahnish.

item.title: Germany Promised to Step Up Militarily. Its Budget Says Differently.
item.description: After Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, Chancellor Olaf Scholz vowed a revolution in defense strategy. But the math is not adding up.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany at a NATO summit in Washington this month.

item.title: Same-Sex Couples in South Korea Win Landmark Rights Ruling
item.description: The country’s Supreme Court said same-sex couples qualify for dependent coverage under the national health insurance, a decision that could have wider ramifications.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: Why Is Venezuela’s President, Nicolás Maduro, on the Ballot 13 Times?
item.description: President Nicolás Maduro will appear over and over again on Venezuela’s presidential ballot. That is by design, government critics say.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky and Gray Beltran

item.title: If Maduro Wins, Venezuelans Vow to Leave
item.description: As many as one-third of Venezuelans would consider migrating if the country’s authoritarian leader is given another six years in power in an election set for July 28, one poll showed.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz and Adriana Loureiro Fernandez
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Leonela Colmenares, 28, an opposition activist, is considering a journey to the U.S. border. She spent years protesting everything from failing public services to the jailing of her activist colleagues.

item.title: Ukraine Loses Hard-Won Position Near Dnipro River in the South
item.description: Soldiers and military analysts said an operation to establish a foothold on the river’s Russian-controlled eastern bank was bloody and hard to justify.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier with an anti aircraft cannon in the Kherson region last month.

item.title: U.K. Failed in Handling of Covid Pandemic, Inquiry Report Says
item.description: The British authorities prepared for the wrong pandemic, with an outdated plan overly focused on influenza, an official investigation reported.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Royal Free Hospital in London in March 2020. The report is the first from an inquiry established in 2021 by the then prime minister, Boris Johnson.

item.title: Marine Tondelier, the ‘Other Marine’ of French Politics, Hits Back
item.description: Marine Tondelier, leader of the Green Party, helped bring the left together to win France’s parliamentary elections. Now can she help keep it from falling apart?
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: Marine Tondelier, the Green leader, applauding the results of the second round of France’s legislative election in Paris on July 7.

item.title: Student Protests in Bangladesh Turn Deadly: What to Know
item.description: Seventeen people have been killed in violent clashes between the police and students protesting a quota system used to fill coveted civil service jobs.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das and Saif Hasnat
item.media:description: Clashes between the police and people who oppose a quota system n Dhaka, the capital of Bangladesh, on Thursday.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: A pivotal moment in the White House race.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Donald Trump gave a speech in Milwaukee accepting the Republican presidential nomination, as screens showed images from the attempt on his life last weekend.

item.title: A Border Crossing Shuttered for Months Traps Sick and Wounded in Gaza
item.description: The Rafah crossing to Egypt has been closed since Israel captured it in early May, blocking the only route out of the territory for thousands of Palestinians who desperately need medical care.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: A 9-year-old Palestinian girl who suffered burns during an Israeli bombardment was treated at Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in Deir al-Balah, central Gaza, in June.

item.title: Italian Monks Rebuild Quake-Ravaged Monastery, Giving Hope to Region
item.description: Eight years after devastating earthquakes ravaged central Italy, the reopening of a monastery is an inspiration for an area still struggling to recover.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Alessandro Penso for The New York Times
item.media:description: One of the reconstructed buildings at the monastery, which perches on a green hillside over Norcia, a town in central Italy.

item.title: A Tip Sheet to Help Decipher American Politics
item.description: With the presidential campaign in a stretch of discord and profound uncertainty, here are a few pieces that provide understanding and context.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: At the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee, Wis., on Wednesday.

item.title: Large Earthquake Rocks Northern Chile
item.description: There were no immediate reports of injuries or damage after the 7.4 magnitude earthquake.
item.dc:creator: Andrés R. Martínez

item.title: Pressure Builds on Netanyahu as Visit to Washington Nears
item.description: A planned speech to Congress by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has made clear the serious divisions he faces back home.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Protesters in Tel Aviv on Thursday calling for the release of the hostages held by Hamas.

item.title: Friday Briefing: U.S. Presidential Race at a Crossroads
item.description: Plus, security failures at the Trump rally.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: Donald Trump will address the final day of the Republican convention.

item.title: Dig at Meloni’s Height Could Cost Reporter in Italy 5,000 Euros
item.description: A lawsuit that Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni won is one of several she has filed against critics. Press-freedom groups say it is a concerning practice.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni of Italy at the Group of 7 summit in Fasano last month. A judge found a journalist guilty of defaming her over an insult.

item.title: At 5, She Picked Up Chess as a Pandemic Hobby. At 9, She’s a Prodigy.
item.description: Bodhana Sivanandan, a fourth-grader, has become one of England’s best players just a few years after discovering chess during pandemic lockdown.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Sam Bush for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bodhana Sivanandan will represent England at the Chess Olympiad.

item.title: A Daily Pill to Prevent S.T.I.s? It May Work, Scientists Say.
item.description: A common antibiotic, doxycycline, greatly reduced cases of syphilis, gonorrhea and chlamydia when taken every day, a study found.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases
item.media:description: The C.D.C. recommends that gay and bisexual men and transgender women who have had an S.T.I. in the last year or who may be at risk for one take doxycycline within 72 hours of unprotected sex.

item.title: Von der Leyen Secures Second E.U. Term, but It’s a New World Out There
item.description: The German conservative, a steadfast U.S. ally, gained European Parliament approval to lead the European Commission for another five years. She’ll face tumult at home and abroad.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: Ursula von der Leyen addressing the European Parliament in Strasbourg, France, on Thursday.

item.title: The Myth of Migrant Crime
item.description: Republicans suggest that immigrants are especially likely to be criminals. The data shows the opposite.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants waiting to be taken to a shelter in Chicago.

item.title: Pressure Mounts on Netanyahu to Seal a Cease-Fire Deal Before Speech to Congress
item.description: The Israeli leader’s speech before a divided Congress next week is likely to be contentious, particularly if he does not close a deal with Hamas to end the war before he travels to Washington.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel at the Knesset, Israel’s Parliament, in Jerusalem on Wednesday.

item.title: America’s Allies in Middle East See Some Advantages in Potential 2nd Trump Presidency
item.description: As Republicans meet this week for their convention, leaders in Israel, Saudi Arabia and Egypt are considering what a second Trump presidency could mean for their domestic and regional agendas.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Vivian Yee and Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: Then-President Donald J. Trump met with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel in 2020.

item.title: Fire at Shopping Mall in Southwestern China Kills 16
item.description: Dozens were trapped inside the building when the fire started on Wednesday evening in Sichuan Province, local authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang

item.title: Two Dead in Canada From Contaminated Milk Substitutes
item.description: The Silk and Great Value brand drinks made from nuts, oats and coconuts were pulled from stores last week.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Unsweetened almond milk carrying the Silk brand was among the drinks recalled by the Canada Food Inspection Agency last week.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: President Biden’s third bout with Covid sidelined him as he was trying to re-energize his campaign in Nevada.

item.title: Zelensky Among European Leaders Meeting in Churchill’s Birthplace
item.description: More than 45 European leaders, including President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, met in England on Thursday. Fears over the continent’s security loomed large.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain, surrounded by the leaders of Denmark, Ukraine, the European Council and Moldova, at the summit in Blenheim Palace, near Oxford, England, on Thursday.

item.title: Watch Rare Siamese Crocodiles Hatching
item.description: The largest population of the endangered Siamese crocodiles this century hatched in Cambodia, a big moment for the conservation of a wild species once on the brink of extinction.
item.dc:creator: Austyn Gaffney

item.title: Thursday Briefing: J.D. Vance Takes the Stage
item.description: Plus, Israel estimates the toll on Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: Before this year, Senator J.D. Vance never attended a national political convention.

item.title: Pentagon Warns ISIS Attacks Could Double This Year
item.description: Attacks claimed by ISIS in Iraq and Syria are on track to double last year’s total, the U.S. military said in a report, as the terrorist group’s affiliates become increasingly deadly elsewhere around the world.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Islamic State flag in a bombed-out militant headquarters in 2017 in Mosul, Iraq.

item.title: Britain Approves Lab-Grown Meat for Pet Food
item.description: British dogs and cats are set to become the first animals in Europe to chow down on meat cultivated from chicken cells.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg

item.title: A Milan Airport Is Now Named for Berlusconi. Cue the ‘Bunga-Bunga’ Memes.
item.description: The decision to name Italy’s second-largest passenger hub after the divisive media mogul and politician, who died in 2023, has prompted outrage and protests.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Terminal 1 at Milan’s Malpensa Airport, which is now named International Airport Milan Malpensa — Silvio Berlusconi.

item.title: E.U. Court Rebukes European Commission Over Covid Vaccine Contracts
item.description: The court ruled that the European Commission wrongly withheld information, casting a shadow on its leader, Ursula von der Leyen, before a crucial vote on her future.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman received a Covid-19 vaccine near Paris in 2021. The European Union’s initial vaccine campaign was marred by a slow start.

item.title: In a Porridge Box, an Ancient Treasure Mysteriously Arrives in Dublin
item.description: The National Museum of Ireland received two copper Bronze Age ax heads in the mail. Now it needs to figure out who found them.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins

item.title: Wall St. Journal Reporter Says She Was Fired Over Hong Kong Union Role
item.description: The journalist accused her former employer of failing to stand up for press freedom, a claim that the newspaper rejected.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:description: Selina Cheng, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal, was elected chair of the Hong Kong Journalists Association in June.

item.title: King’s Speech Promises a Changed U.K.
item.description: From plans to tackle climate change to ending the role of hereditary legislators, the ceremonial King’s Speech showcased the progressive priorities of Britain’s Labour government.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: King Charles III formally opened Britain’s Parliament on Wednesday, presenting the priorities of Britain’s new Labour government.

item.title: Moving in Childhood Contributes to Depression, Study Finds
item.description: A study of more than a million Danes found that frequent moves in childhood had a bigger effect than poverty on adult mental health risk.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Researchers found that people who moved more than once within the ages of 10 and 15 were 61 percent more likely to suffer from depression in adulthood compared to counterparts who had not moved.

item.title: Judge Orders Boss Who Coughed at Employee During Pandemic to Pay Damages
item.description: The ruling by a tribunal judge in Britain highlighted the challenges and missteps businesses encountered during the early days of the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Barriers in central London in 2020, set up to allow more room for pedestrians because of Covid-19 social distancing measures.

item.title: Paris Mayor Swims in Beautified Seine Ahead of Olympic Games
item.description: Anne Hidalgo swam in the cleaned-up waters of the capital’s river, fulfilling a promise that has become a symbol of the Olympic Games that start this month.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anne Hidalgo, the mayor of Paris, and Tony Estanguet, the head of the Paris Olympics Committee, prepared to swim in the Seine in central Paris on Wednesday.

item.title: Israel’s Military Says It Eliminated Half the Leadership of Hamas Military Wing
item.description: The military said that it had killed or captured around 14,000 combatants in Gaza since the war’s start but left considerable ambiguity about the figure.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: The collapsed minaret of a mosque in Nuseirat, in the central Gaza Strip, on Wednesday.

item.title: Hiker’s Death Prompts Move to Allow Wider Bear Cull in Romania
item.description: But some experts described the planned cull as excessive and said it would not keep people safe.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: A bear on a street in Covasna, a town in central Romania, last fall.

item.title: World’s Rarest Whale Washes Up on New Zealand Beach
item.description: Only six specimens of the spade-toothed whale have ever been identified. This carcass could be the first that scientists are able to dissect.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: New Zealand Department of Conservation, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Scientists believe the carcass that washed up in Otago, New Zealand, this month could give them their first opportunity to dissect a spade-toothed whale.

item.title: Biden vs. His Party
item.description: The Democratic Party’s Biden dilemma is unresolved, even as the momentum against him slows.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: President Biden last week.

item.title: Trump Says Taiwan Should Pay for U.S. Defense
item.description: Trump also accused Taiwan of sinking the U.S. semiconductor sector, signaling he wants a more transactional approach to shielding the island from China.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: Former President Donald Trump backstage before entering the Convention Hall on the first day of the RNC Convention in Milwaukee on Monday.

item.title: Heat Wave in Ukraine Further Strains Its Electricity Grid
item.description: To prevent a collapse of the electricity system, crippled by months of Russian attacks, the authorities have imposed rolling blackouts. Experts say it’s a harbinger of what’s to come this winter.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Generators powering a row of shops in the Podil neighborhood of Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital, on Tuesday.

item.title: How France Blocked the Far Right
item.description: The French had a far-right government before, one that collaborated with the Nazis. When casting ballots even today, that is not an easy thing to forget.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Posters showing candidates for France’s second round of legislative elections outside the City Hall in Saintes last week.

item.title: Traces of Cyanide Found in Bangkok Hotel Room Where Six Died
item.description: A case that shocked Thailand, the police indicated on Wednesday, was one of murder-suicide.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:description: A news conference Wednesday at a Bangkok police station about the six bodies found in a downtown hotel room.

item.title: Flash Flooding in Toronto Leads to Rescues and Power Outages
item.description: More than 167,000 customers lost power on Tuesday after severe thunderstorms.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Arlyn Mcadorey/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Cars are partially submerged in flood waters in the Don Valley following heavy rain in Toronto on Tuesday.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: President Biden’s growing isolation.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The Democratic Party is still deeply divided about President Biden’s electoral prospects.
